block.p: Yahoo's Quarterly Profit Beats Analysts' Estimates Yahoo posted better-than-expected quarterly earnings, quelling investor concerns that consolidation and business failures among struggling dot-coms might hurt its revenue base.

Yahoo reported net income of $65.5 million, or 11 cents a share, exceeding analysts' projections of 10 cents a share. Revenue was $270.1 million, up from $128.6 million in the period a year earlier, and beat analysts' forecasts of $240 million. Shares of Yahoo fell $4.50, to $105.50, before the results were announced, but they rebounded as high as $121 in after-hours trading. [Page C10.]

China Looks to Pick Up Reform Pace Though China has been marching famously on the road toward economic change for more than two decades, barriers to capital formation keep most private businesses from providing more than a handful of jobs. There is growing pressure to change that. With World Trade Organization membership expected to open the domestic market wider to foreign companies, foreigners could take over a huge part of the economy unless China unleashes private entrepreneurs soon. [A1.]
A majority of Senate Republicans urged their leader, Trent Lott, to delay until September a vote on a major bill establishing permanent normal trade relations with China. [A5.]

Lessons on Capability and Integrity Ronald W. Dollens, chief executive of Guidant, says he learned life's lessons from his father during drives to and from work at the family grocery store: ''He taught me about integrity and respecting people no matter what their stature. He had a wallhanging in the kitchen: 'Don't try to teach a pig to sing. It wastes your time and annoys the pig.' I have that saying framed in my office. It reminds me that you have to start with a certain amount of capability or you're pretty limited in what you can do.'' The Boss. [C8.]

Dow Rises Again, but Nasdaq Falls The Dow Jones industrial average rose for a third consecutive session, gaining 80.61 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,727.19. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.26 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,480.88, but technology stocks slumped, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 23.87 points, or 0.6 percent, to 3,956.42. [C10.]

Virgin Atlantic Ushers In Cell Calls Virgin Atlantic Airways has introduced a system that routes incoming cellular calls to handsets at passengers' seats. Incoming calls ring quietly on passenger earphones or are announced as a text message on in-seat video screens. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C9.]
Most United States airlines said that they would reduce some fares by about 25 percent into December, trying to maintain the strong traffic levels seen recently. [C9.]

Lawyer in Coke Case Is Restricted A federal judge ordered a Florida lawyer who is representing four black former Coca-Cola employees in a racial-discrimination lawsuit not to interfere with the settlement reached last month between Coke and four other employees with similar claims. [C21.]

Profit Triples at International Paper International Paper, the maker of paper and forest products, said that its second-quarter profit more than tripled as a result of higher prices and cost-cutting. The results beat Wall Street expectations by a penny. Shares of International Paper rose $3, to $35.25. International Paper had dropped 43 percent this year. [C2.]

Harper to Acquire British Publisher HarperCollins Publishers agreed to acquire Fourth Estate, a small and highly regarded British publishing house based in London whose authors include the popular historian Dava Sobel and the novelist Annie Proulx. Terms were not disclosed. [C6.]

Bank Strike Ends in South Korea The South Korean government and labor leaders agreed to end a strike by bank workers who walked off their jobs to protest mergers that could lead to thousands of layoffs. [C4.]
